title: What causes opioid addiction, and why is it so tough to combat? - Mike Davis

multiple-choice.question: What ancient civilizations were known to use the poppy plant for its medicinal and euphoric effects?
What is the term for substances made directly from the poppy plant, such as morphine and codeine?
Why are opioid drugs highly addictive?

options.label: A
options.text: They bind to opioid receptors in the brain, releasing dopamine and suppressing noradrenaline.

options.label: B
options.text: They are highly effective painkillers with no side effects.

options.label: C
options.text: They are easily available and affordable.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a long history of use in ancient civilizations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of long-term opioid use on the body's opioid receptors?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of opioid receptors increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of opioid receptors decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: The opioid receptors become more responsive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of abrupt cessation of opioid use in someone who is physically dependent?

options.label: A
options.text: The body becomes less sensitive to noradrenaline.

options.label: B
options.text: The body becomes more sensitive to noradrenaline, leading to withdrawal symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: The body experiences no changes in noradrenaline sensitivity.

options.label: D
options.text: The body immediately returns to its normal state.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people who are addicted to opioids often continue using the drugs despite the risks?

options.label: D
options.text: To cope with mental health conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of naloxone in combating opioid overdose?

options.label: A
options.text: It activates opioid receptors to increase dopamine release.

options.label: B
options.text: It blocks opioid receptors to reverse an overdose.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases noradrenaline levels to counteract opioid effects.

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases opioid cravings to prevent relapse.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common obstacle to seeking treatment for opioid addiction?
What is the purpose of opioid maintenance programs?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide short-term detoxification from opioids.

options.label: B
options.text: To offer long-term medication-assisted therapy to eliminate opioid abuse.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide counseling and behavioral therapy only.

options.label: D
options.text: To prescribe opioid painkillers for chronic pain management.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the helpline operated by the Department of Health and Human Services for individuals struggling with opioid use in the United States?

title: This-song to teach the sight word "this"

What word is being spelled out in the transcript?
What is the tone of the transcript?

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: How does the transcript relate to the concept of language and meaning?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows how language can be used to convey complex ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the importance of clear communication.

options.label: C
options.text: It plays with the sounds and rhythms of language.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the repetition of "t h i s t h i s t h i s spells this"?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: How might the transcript be interpreted as a commentary on the nature of language and reality?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that language is a fixed and reliable way to describe reality.

options.label: B
options.text: It implies that language is playful and flexible.

options.label: C
options.text: It argues that language is insufficient to capture the complexity of reality.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no relation to the nature of language and reality.

title: What is society? | US society for children

multiple-choice.question: What is a society?

options.text: A large group of people who share the same laws, rights, and resources

options.text: A group of people who speak the same language

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who belong to the same cultural community

options.label: C
options.text: The Lopez family living in New York and the Wilson family living in California

options.label: D
options.text: The Lopez family living in Florida and the Wilson family living in Canada

multiple-choice.question: What do members of American society share in common?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they work at the same place

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they belong to the same cultural community

options.label: C
options.text: A group of animal protection volunteers

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who belong to the same cultural community

options.text: They must speak the same language

options.label: C
options.text: They share common laws, rights, and resources

options.label: D
options.text: They must belong to the same cultural community

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they live in the same neighborhood

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they speak the same language

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a society and a community?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They must communicate with each other daily

options.label: D
options.text: They must meet in person regularly

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Which is better: Soap or hand sanitizer? - Alex Rosenthal and Pall Thordarson

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why soap and water are effective in destroying the coronavirus?

options.label: A
options.text: The soap molecules are attracted to the virus's lipid bilayer.

options.label: B
options.text: The soap molecules compete with the lipids in the virus's shell, breaking it apart.

options.label: C
options.text: The soap molecules form a protective layer around the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: The soap molecules change the pH of the environment, making it inhospitable to the virus.

multiple-choice.question: How do hand sanitizers work to destroy the coronavirus?

options.label: A
options.text: By forming bubbles around the virus particles.

options.label: B
options.text: By competing with the lipids in the virus's shell, breaking it apart.

options.label: C
options.text: By removing the hydrophobic effect and allowing the molecules to move freely.

options.label: D
options.text: By changing the pH of the environment, making it inhospitable to the virus.

multiple-choice.question: Why do doctors recommend washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the soap takes 20 seconds to activate.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the virus takes 20 seconds to die.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the intricate landscape of the hand requires time to cover all areas.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the soap needs to penetrate deep into the skin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using soap and water over hand sanitizer?

options.label: A
options.text: Soap and water is more convenient to use on the go.

options.label: B
options.text: Soap and water is more effective at killing the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: Soap and water washes away dirt that could hide virus particles and is easier to fully cover hands.

options.label: D
options.text: Soap and water is less expensive than hand sanitizer.

multiple-choice.question: Why may hand sanitizer be more effective against certain viruses, such as rhinoviruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is more convenient to use.

options.label: B
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is more effective at killing all types of viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the surface proteins of the virus are vulnerable to the destabilizing effect of hand sanitizer.

options.label: D
options.text: Because hand sanitizer is less expensive than soap and water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the effect that allows lipids to stick together in the virus's shell?
What is the purpose of the amphiphiles in soap?

options.label: A
options.text: To form bubbles around the virus particles.

options.label: B
options.text: To compete with the lipids in the virus's shell, breaking it apart.

options.label: C
options.text: To remove the hydrophobic effect and allow the molecules to move freely.

options.label: D
options.text: To change the pH of the environment, making it inhospitable to the virus.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to follow the advice of accredited medical professionals during an outbreak?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have the most up-to-date information on the virus.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can provide personalized advice on how to protect yourself.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can recommend the most effective method of destroying the virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the structure that some viruses, such as rhinoviruses, have instead of a lipid membrane?
What is one solution being developed to provide clean drinking water for hand-washing in communities that lack access to it?

options.label: A
options.text: A device that uses salt, water, and a car battery to make chlorinated water.

options.label: B
options.text: A device that uses UV light to purify water.

options.label: C
options.text: A device that uses filters to remove impurities from water.

options.label: D
options.text: A device that uses boiling water to kill pathogens.

options.text: To demonstrate phonetic similarity between words

options.text: To emphasize the shark's friendly nature

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of rhythm and rhyme

title: The Princess and the Pea - Read aloud picture book

multiple-choice.question: Who is the author of the story "The Princess and the Pea"?
What was the prince searching for in his travels around the world?
Why was the prince unhappy when he returned home from his travels?

options.label: A
options.text: He had found too many princesses

options.label: B
options.text: He had not found a real princess

multiple-choice.question: What event occurred on the evening the princess arrived at the castle?
How did the old queen test the princess to determine if she was real?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking her a series of questions

options.label: B
options.text: By placing a pea under 20 mattresses and 20 feather beds

options.label: C
options.text: By making her sleep in the royal guest room

options.label: D
options.text: By inviting her to a royal dinner

multiple-choice.question: What was the princess's complaint the next morning?

options.label: D
options.text: She had felt something hard in the bed and was black and blue

multiple-choice.question: Why did the royal family believe the princess was real?

options.label: C
options.text: Because she had felt the pea through 20 mattresses and 20 feather beds

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the pea after the story?

options.label: B
options.text: It was put in the royal museum

options.label: C
options.text: It was given to the princess as a gift

options.label: D
options.text: It was lost in the storm

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the prince's search for a real princess?

options.label: B
options.text: He found one, but she refused to marry him

options.label: C
options.text: He found one and married her

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the princess feeling the pea through the multiple mattresses and feather beds?

options.label: C
options.text: It showed she was delicate and sensitive

title: The sentence song

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of a capital letter?

options.label: B
options.text: It is only used at the end of a sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in questions.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three punctuation marks that can be used to end a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: Period, exclamation mark, and question mark

multiple-choice.question: Why does the sentence "Do you like bugs?" end with a question mark?
What is the purpose of using a capital letter at the beginning of a sentence?

options.label: C
options.text: To signify the start of a new sentence

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is an example of a sentence that ends with an exclamation mark?
What is a common characteristic of sentences?

options.label: A
options.text: They always start with a small letter.

options.label: B
options.text: They always end with a comma.

options.label: C
options.text: They always start with a capital letter and end with a punctuation mark.

multiple-choice.question: How does the sentence "My dog is great" end?
Why is a capital letter used in the sentence "There is a monster!"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a small letter.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the start of a new sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not a sentence.

multiple-choice.question: What type of sentence is "Do you like bugs?"?
What is the purpose of using a period at the end of a sentence?

options.label: C
options.text: To signify the end of a sentence

title: This sea creature breathes through its butt - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What phylum do sea cucumbers belong to?
What is the primary function of the respiratory tree in sea cucumbers?

options.label: A
options.text: To extract oxygen from the air

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question: What is the unique feature of the mutable collagenous tissue (MCT) in sea cucumbers?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a rigid structure that provides support

options.label: B
options.text: It is a gel-like tissue that can change its stiffness

options.label: C
options.text: It is a fluid that helps with locomotion

options.label: D
options.text: It is a solid that aids in reproduction

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of an animal that takes advantage of the sea cucumber's rhythmic action to take shelter?
Factual Question: What is the name given to the defense mechanism where sea cucumbers shoot out their internal organs?
Application Question: What would be the likely outcome if sea cucumbers were to disappear from the ocean ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: The ocean would become more polluted

options.label: B
options.text: The ocean would become cleaner and more oxygenated

options.label: D
options.text: The ocean's ecosystem would remain unchanged

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question: What can be inferred about the importance of sea cucumbers in the ocean ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a keystone species that plays a crucial role in maintaining the ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: They are a dominant species that outcompetes other species for resources

options.label: C
options.text: They are a redundant species that can be replaced by other species

options.label: D
options.text: They are a species that has no impact on the ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of animal biomass that sea cucumbers comprise on the deep sea floor?
Conceptual Question: How do sea cucumbers contribute to the formation of coral reefs?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a habitat for coral polyps

options.label: C
options.text: By excreting nutrients that aid in coral formation

options.label: D
options.text: By preventing coral growth through competition

title: Can you trust your eyes?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the video about perception and vision?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain the absolute nature of color and physical properties.

options.label: B
options.text: To show how our brains can be tricked into seeing different colors.

options.label: C
options.text: To discuss the complex biological and neurological factors of perception.

options.label: D
options.text: To demonstrate how our perception of the world is relative.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the illusion that shows two grey rectangular columns as different shades of grey, even though they are the same?
According to the video, what is the purpose of our senses, specifically our eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide us with an absolute color or physical property of our external reality.

options.label: B
options.text: To interpret what we see as efficiently as possible in order to interact with the environment.

options.label: C
options.text: To trick our brains into seeing different colors.

options.label: D
options.text: To show the absolute nature of color and physical properties.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our perception of the tile's color when the surrounding shadow is removed?

options.label: C
options.text: The tile's color remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The tile's color changes to a different color.

multiple-choice.question: Why does our brain compensate by interpreting the tile as being lighter than it appears?

options.label: A
options.text: Because shadows make objects look lighter.

options.label: B
options.text: Because shadows make objects look darker.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the tile is actually lighter.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the tile is actually darker.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of introducing colors to the two grey rectangular columns?

options.label: A
options.text: The columns appear as different shades of grey.

options.label: B
options.text: The columns appear as the same shade of grey.

options.label: C
options.text: The columns appear as different colors.

options.label: D
options.text: The columns appear as the same color.

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what do scientists not fully understand?

options.label: C
options.text: The phenomenon of perception and vision.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our perception of the middle bar's color when the background gradient is removed?

options.label: C
options.text: The bar's color remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The bar's color changes to a different color.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for our perception being relative?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brains judge color and brightness in context.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains judge color and brightness absolutely.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our senses provide us with an absolute color or physical property.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our senses provide us with a relative color or physical property.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall message of the video regarding our perception and vision?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should always trust our eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should never trust our eyes.

options.label: C
options.text: That our perception is relative and can be influenced by various factors.

options.label: D
options.text: That our perception is absolute and cannot be influenced by various factors.

title: Frederick Douglass for kids (cartoon biography)

multiple-choice.question: What was Frederick Douglass's occupation, and what did he fight for?

options.label: A
options.text: A teacher who fought for women's rights

options.label: B
options.text: A politician who fought for African American rights

options.label: C
options.text: An abolitionist who fought against slavery

options.label: D
options.text: A writer who fought for environmental rights

multiple-choice.question: What was the law regarding reading for African Americans during slavery?

options.label: A
options.text: They were required to read and write

options.label: B
options.text: They were encouraged to read but not write

options.label: C
options.text: They were not allowed to read or have someone teach them how to read

options.label: D
options.text: They were allowed to read but only certain books

multiple-choice.question: Who helped Frederick Douglass learn the basics of reading?
How did Frederick Douglass continue to learn how to read after his teacher was stopped?

options.label: A
options.text: He attended a secret school for slaves

options.label: B
options.text: He watched other white children learn in school and taught himself

options.label: C
options.text: He was homeschooled by his mother

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't continue to learn how to read

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence for Frederick Douglass when his master found out he was teaching other slaves to read?

options.label: A
options.text: He was rewarded with more privileges

options.label: B
options.text: He was ignored by his master

options.label: C
options.text: He was beaten by his master

options.label: D
options.text: He was sold to another plantation

multiple-choice.question: How did Frederick Douglass escape to the North?

options.label: A
options.text: He walked for miles through the forest

options.label: B
options.text: He borrowed the papers of a free sailor

options.label: C
options.text: He was helped by the Underground Railroad

multiple-choice.question: What did Frederick Douglass write that told about his life experiences?

options.label: D
options.text: A play about the Civil War

multiple-choice.question: Why did Frederick Douglass escape to Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to explore a new country

options.label: B
options.text: He was afraid of being captured by his master

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to join the military

multiple-choice.question: Which president did Frederick Douglass advise during the Civil War?
What was Frederick Douglass's impact on African American history?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a leader who fought for slavery

options.label: B
options.text: He was a leader who fought against slavery and poor treatment of African Americans

options.label: C
options.text: He was a leader who fought for women's rights

options.label: D
options.text: He was a leader who fought for environmental rights

title: 6 ways to start a sentence | Sentence structure | Learn to write

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the best ways to start a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: To describe the location of the subject

options.label: B
options.text: To tell what the subject is doing

multiple-choice.question: What type of word can be used to start a sentence to describe where something is happening?

options.label: C
options.text: It describes the location of the subject

options.label: D
options.text: It tells what the subject is doing
